title: Canadians to help develop, test potential COVID-19 vaccine from Chinese company | CBC News
description: The National Research Council of Canada said Tuesday it will work with a Chinese company to try to develop its potential vaccine for COVID-19 more quickly.
content: The National Research Council of Canada said Tuesday it will work with a Chinese company to try to develop its potential vaccine for COVID-19 more quickly.The Chinese company, CanSino Biologics, is already conducting human clinical trials for its vaccine.Federal governments the world over have said vaccines are urgently needed to allow mass gatherings to resume. But that's only if clinical trials in thousands of human volunteers show safety and efficacy before shots go into the arms of vast swaths of the general public.As of April, five vaccine candidates have moved into clinical development in early stage human trials, including CanSino's, called Ad5-nCoV.The collaboration announced on Tuesday will allow Canada's publicly funded research council to try to scale up the technology needed to produce enough of the candidate vaccine to protect Canadians.Matthew Herder, director of the Health Law Institute at Dalhousie University's law school in Halifax, evaluated contracts for the Canadian Ebola vaccine. That vaccine followed a similar path from the lab bench to mass production. Herder welcomed the NRC announcement and awaits the details."I think it showcases the power of the public sector … to play a key role in the development of vaccines," he said.There could also be strings attached on pricing, how much manufacturing can be done in Canada to meet both domestic and international needs, and equity of access, he said.The NRC plans to use a cell line its scientists developed during Ebola vaccine research.WATCH | Steps to vaccine safety and efficacy:Lakshmi Krishnan, director general of the NRC's Human Health Therapeutics Research Centre, said the trials in Canada will complement and expand on what's been done in China."We're bringing back home a Canadian technology, and we're able to have the most advanced vaccine candidate in the world potentially available for Canadians in short order," Krishnan said. A Phase 1 trial for the Ebola vaccine took place at the Canadian Centre for Vaccinology in Halifax. The coronavirus vaccine will initially also be tested on healthy human volunteers there, subject to Health Canada's approval.If successful, then Phase 2 trials could start in the fall at hospitals in other provinces with a vaccine available for non-commercial use produced on Canadian soil for front line workers and those at risk in late 2020 or early 2021, she said.Dr. Ross Upshur of the University of Toronto's Dalla Lana School of Public Health studies global health ethics. He isn't involved in the vaccine trials."You can't really tell how effective something is until you've got a large number of people and it's out in the field," Upshur said. The federal government's previously announced $44 million for upgrades to the NRC's facility in Montreal also aims to allow for domestic production if the vaccine candidate pans out.Separately on Tuesday, the federal government pledged $600 million over five years to support Gavi, a partnership between governments and the private sector. The group aims to vaccinate children around the world with routine immunizations and supports efforts to stamp out the pandemic globally.Successful vaccines normally take five to 15 years to develop and mass produce.

title: Huawei unveils pricey 5G-ready phone with folding screen | CBC News
description: China's Huawei has unveiled a new folding-screen phone, joining the latest trend for bendable devices as it challenges the global smartphone market's dominant players, Apple and Samsung.
content: China's Huawei unveiled a new folding-screen phone on Sunday, joining the latest trend for bendable devices as it challenges the global smartphone market's dominant players, Apple and Samsung.Huawei revealed its Mate X phone on the eve of MWC Barcelona, a four-day showcase of mobile devices in Spain, as the company battles U.S. allegations it is a cybersecurity risk.The device can be used on superfast next-generation mobile networks that are due to come online over the next decade. Device makers are looking to folding screens as the industry's next big thing to help them break out of an innovation malaise, although most analysts think the market is limited, at least in the early days.The Mate X is the answer to a question Huawei faced as it sought to satisfy smartphone users' demands for bigger screens and longer battery life, said Richard Yu, CEO of its consumer business group."How can we bring the more big innovation to this smartphone industry?" Yu said at a glitzy media launch.The Mate X will sell for 2,299 euros ($2,600 US, or $3,400 Cdn) when it goes on sale by mid-year. That's even more than Samsung's recently revealed Galaxy Fold, priced at nearly $2,000 US.The Mate X's screen wraps around the outside so users can still view it when it's closed, unlike the Galaxy Fold, which has a screen that folds shut. Unfolded, the Mate X's screen is 20 cm diagonally, making it the size of a small tablet.Yu said Huawei engineers spent three years working on the device's hinge, which doesn't leave a gap when shut."No matter how innovative and technology-advanced the new device is, it will take a lot more time for a critical mass of consumers to experience the benefits of foldable phones and 5G technology," Forrester analyst Thomas Husson said.Huawei still "has to find its own brand voice to differentiate from Samsung and Apple and stop acting as a technology challenger."Huawei Technologies is trying to raise its profile in the fiercely competitive smartphone market. Almost everyone with a smartphone has heard of Apple and Samsung, the top device makers, and Google, the power behind Android's pervasive software.Huawei, a Chinese company with a name many people in the West don't know how to pronounce (it's "HWA-way"), wants to join the market's upper echelon.It's getting close. Samsung was the No. 1 smartphone seller for all of last year, followed by Apple, according to research firm International Data Corp. Huawei came third, though in some quarters it took second place, IDC data showed.The company stealthily became an industry star by plowing into new markets, honing its technology, and developing a line-up of phones that offer affordable options for low-income households and luxury models that are siphoning upper-crust sales from Apple and Samsung in China and Europe.But Huawei's products are few and far between in the U.S. The scarcity stems from long-running security concerns that the company could facilitate digital espionage on behalf of China's government. Washington has been lobbying European allies to keep its equipment out of new 5G networks.The cloud over Huawei also includes U.S. criminal charges filed last month against the company and its chief financial officer, Meng Wanzhou, who U.S. prosecutors want to extradite from Canada. They accuse her of fraud and say the company stole trade secrets, including technology that mobile carrier T-Mobile used to test smartphones.Huawei is making its push at a time that both Samsung and Apple are struggling with declining smartphone sales amid a lull in industry innovation that is causing more consumers to hold on to their devices until they wear out instead of upgrading to the latest model as quickly as they once did.The company sells high-priced smartphones as well as an extensive range of cheaper models priced from $200 to $600 that offer a good camera and other features most consumers want, analysts said.But Huawei wouldn't be where it is today if it had been content focusing merely on China and other Asian markets.The company took a huge step forward several years ago when it began pouring millions into promoting its brand and building partnerships in major European markets such as Germany, France, Britain, Spain and Italy. Research firm Gartner estimates it now sells about 13 per cent of its phones in Europe.As for the U.S., Huawei can only make so much headway as long as the government is casting the company as a cyber-villain, said Gartner analyst Tuong Nguyen."Brand building is a long-term exercise, but it's going to be especially difficult in the U.S. because of the way they have branded all of China," he said. "The barriers in the U.S. are just getting more difficult."

title: New Brunswick goes 4 days without new cases of COVID-19 | CBC News
description: It's been four days since Public Health has seen a new case of COVID-19 in New Brunswick.
content: It's been four days since New Brunswick Public Health has seen a new case of COVID-19 in the province.There is still one active case of the respiratory virus in the Fredericton region, also known as Region 3. That person is not in hospital.Before the case was announced last Thursday, New Brunswick had gone more than two weeks without a new case.There have been 166 confirmed cases of COVID-19 since the outbreak started in March, and 163 people recover from the virus. Two people, both residents of a long-term care home in Atholville, died.So far, the province has conducted 46,489 tests for the disease, according to the dashboard information published Monday.It's been more than a week since the Atlantic travel bubble has opened between New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland.Prince Edward Island announced a new case of COVID-19 on Sunday, a health care worker at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Charlottetown. The case came to light after an 80-year-woman who had seen the health care worker at the hospital tested positive. There are currently eight active cases of the virus on the island. Nova Scotia hasn't had any new cases of COVID-19 in five consecutive days. Newfoundland recorded its first active case of COVID-19 on Friday after 43 days without any cases. No new cases of the virus have been announced over the weekend.To date, there has been 46,489 tests performed for COVID-19 in New Brunswick.People concerned they might have COVID-19 symptoms can take a self-assessment test on the government website at gnb.ca. Public Health says symptoms shown by people with COVID-19 have included: a fever above 38 C, a new cough or worsening chronic cough, sore throat, runny nose, headache, new onset of fatigue, new onset of muscle pain, diarrhea, loss of sense of taste or smell, and difficulty breathing. In children, symptoms have also included purple markings on the fingers and toes.People with one of those symptoms are asked to:Stay at home.Call Tele-Care 811 or their doctor.Describe symptoms and travel history.Follow instructions.

title: Banning Huawei from building 5G network unlikely to seriously hurt Canada's big telcos, analysts say | CBC News
description: If the federal government moves to ban Huawei from Canada's 5G network, it is unlikely to have a major financial impact on two of the country's top communication companies who have partnered with the China-based firm, analysts say.
content: If the federal government moves to ban Huawei from working to build Canada's new 5G network, it is unlikely to have a major financial impact on two of the country's top communications companies who have partnered with the China-based firm, analysts say.Huawei's equipment is already used in telecommunications infrastructure run by Canada's major cellphone carriers, namely BCE and Telus. Those two companies are currently in 5G pretrial stages with Huawei, a company some western intelligence officials consider a security risk due to its links with China's government. As the next-generation wireless technology, 5G promises to deliver much faster internet download speeds — possibly up to 200 times faster than today's LTE networks.Desmond Lau, a telecommunications analyst with investment research firm Veritas, said BCE and Telus have not put a lot of capital into 5G trials, so the financial hit from a ban on Huawei's participation wouldn't be large.    "It doesn't sound like all that much has been spent on 5G," Lau said, adding that neither company has disclosed what they have spent so far. "They also have Nokia as another 5G partner, so they could probably just switch all toward Nokia if they really needed to."BCE and Telus did not respond to inquiries from CBC News about their relationship with Huawei on building Canada's 5G network. The Sydney Morning Herald, an Australian newspaper, has reported that Ottawa could announce a formal ban on Huawei building the 5G network within weeks. Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale has called those reports "speculation.""The issues are being very carefully considered by Canadians. We have not arrived at a conclusion," Goodale told CBC Radio's The House.According to a Scotiabank telecommunications report, both BCE and Telus use radio access networks (RANs), equipment located at the top and bottom of cell sites, produced by Huawei. "To our knowledge, Huawei does not supply the network core, which is software based and considered to be the most sensitive part of the network from a privacy and security perspective," the report states.For years, Huawei has been a source of concern for Western security officials, particularly the U.S., which has tried to convince other countries not to buy equipment from the company.Huawei denies allegations that it conducts espionage on behalf of China and has said it's a market-driven business simply looking to compete internationally."Huawei has been working with Canadian operators on a number of pre-commercial trials in the lead up to 5G," said Scott Bradley, a spokesman for Huawei Canada. "These efforts will ensure Canada is well positioned to be one of the early leaders in 5G globally, and will benefit Canadians in applications as diverse as greatly improving rural service, to spurring new innovations requiring increased speeds and capacity."This next generation technology will also open up what analysts refer to as the "internet of things," which would allow everyday devices and machines be connected to a wireless network. "These ground-breaking trials are laying the foundation for 5G, which will enable the likes of driverless cars; smart cities; new innovations in healthcare; as well as yet-to-be-imagined applications, devices and services powered by astonishingly fast and reliable wireless connections," Telus said in a news release.But with 5G, one of the concerns is that the network would be more vulnerable to attack. If Huawei has some kind of relationship with the Chinese government, the fear is that the company could install a "backdoor" in the 5G network, possibly allowing access to the network, and creating the potential for widespread disruption.New Zealand and Australia have banned Huawei from working on their 5G networks. And British phone carrier BT said it would not use their equipment for its planned 5G mobile network. The U.K. company is removing Huawei equipment from the core of its existing 3G and 4G mobile phone networks.If a similar move to rip out and replace existing Huawei infrastructure were to happen in Canada, it "would obviously be very costly," according to the Scotiabank report.Replacing Huawei products in Canada's existing 3G and 4G mobile networks could cost more than $1.2 billion, Scotiabank's report said. "If logic prevails, even if a ban was to occur, we think it would be on 5G only," said the report. "We believe this will be more manageable" as there is "limited 5G equipment at the cell sites today."

title: Contact tracing for COVID-19 risks erasing civil liberties, says expert | CBC Radio
description: Governments around the world are turning to new measures, including contact tracing, to try to slow the spread of the COVID-19 outbreak. This involves partnering with technology giants and collecting massive amounts of personal data from cellphones. Civil liberties organizations are worried about the potential consequences of these tradeoffs.
content: In an effort to keep the spread of the coronavirus in check, many governments around the world have granted themselves and police expanded powers. As the search for a longer-term solution continues, it raises a key question: how much are we willing to give up in the name of safety?To manage the next phase of the pandemic, governments around the world are turning to new measures, including contact tracing, to try to slow the spread of the disease. That involves partnerships with technology giants and the mass collection of personal data from cellphones. Civil liberties organizations are worried about the potential consequences of these trade-offs."When we talk about location data being particularly invasive, it's because where we are reflects who we are and how we live" said Brenda McPhail, the director of the Privacy, Technology & Surveillance Project at the Canadian Civil Liberties Association."Increasingly, in this age of surveillance capitalism, [data] can be sold and exploited, either to sell you things by corporations or to figure out how you're likely to behave," she said in an interview with Michael Enright, host of The Sunday Edition. "And it's particularly that idea of behavioural assessment … that's of particular concern, in these circumstances in the pandemic."Here are some highlights from their conversation, edited for clarity and condensed.We started out very well in Canada. We took careful, measured steps. As time goes on, as we're more and more afraid, as we're more and more sick of being stuck in our homes and social distancing, as more and more people have no employment income, the cries for governments to do more, to do anything that it takes, is getting really loud. And this is where the risks of surveillance come in. This is where we start hearing, "Any restriction is OK if it helps. So why aren't you tracking people?" Because the best way to control human behaviour is to know exactly what we do at all times.I spent all my professional life thinking about privacy and surveillance in the ways that technology affects those things. Right now, the question is absolutely, "If it will help, save lives and get us through this faster, shouldn't we just give up everything for that goal?"There's a part of me, as a mother, who is worried about her kids, as a daughter who has a mother who's in a high-risk category for this, that says I get that. I get that incredibly visceral reaction that when it comes to a choice between rights and the ability to see the faces of those I love [it] would outweigh that sort of ephemeral connection to an idea of human rights, that I think we do have in Canada. But that right now is starting to feel a little bit shaky. And maybe a little bit privileged. But the rights that form the foundation for our shared values are, in fact, the very values that are helping us get through this crisis.What's remarkable about the social effectiveness of social distancing in Canada is not how many people are getting ticketed for sitting on a bench for too long or talking across their driveway. It's how many of us are actually doing the things that we're told to do. That frankly is the response of people who live in a mature democracy. That's the response of people who share values and are willing to prioritize the common good.If we toss that out the window, even if it helps right now … we're going to reduce our ability to get through another crisis like this in the future. We're going to give up who we are and what we believe, in ways that aren't just going to risk eroding rights over the long-term. It's going to risk erasing them.With some civil liberties, we're probably pretty safe. If following this pandemic, provinces continue to limit travel, for example, there would be a huge outcry. We'd say, "No way. I have mobility rights. I deserve to travel around my home country." And that would not stand in a democracy.The problem with privacy is that we're in a situation where our idea of what privacy means — even our idea of whether or not it's a fundamental human right, which it is recognized as internationally — we are in a position where the idea that privacy is something that corporations or governments can ask us to give away in exchange for a service or convenience is really fundamental. Some of these platforms that we're using to help us navigate our way through this isolation, things like video chats, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram that are allowing us to have some form of human connection during isolation are the very platforms that have habituated us to the idea that, in exchange for the privilege of using them, they get to collect information about us.That's been fundamentally built into the infrastructure of the business model and the internet, in ways that have slowly, already eroded and changed our idea of what privacy we deserve. So the risk in the pandemic is that that process is going to accelerate. And we're going to give up — not just in relation to companies but in relation to the state — the idea that privacy is actually a right and not a privilege.You've got to watch really closely for the idea that privacy is a barrier to public health — because it's not. The reality is there is nothing in privacy law that prevents sharing of epidemiological information that's necessary for public health purposes. There is nothing in privacy law that is a barrier to lawful collection of information. And what it is is a barrier to collecting personal information that's unnecessary and intrusive, that's not proportionate to the benefit that we get from it, either as individuals or as a society.The other thing that we want to watch for is the kind of proposals about tracking our risk, about coming up with some kind of system to label us as safe or unsafe people. There are so many fundamental problems with that kind of social sorting, that it's just not a place that we should be going as Canadians.Click 'listen' above to hear the full interview.

Right now, the question is absolutely, "If it will help, save lives and get us through this faster, shouldn't we just give up everything for that goal?"There's a part of me, as a mother, who is worried about her kids, as a daughter who has a mother who's in a high-risk category for this, that says I get that. I get that incredibly visceral reaction that when it comes to a choice between rights and the ability to see the faces of those I love [it] would outweigh that sort of ephemeral connection to an idea of human rights, that I think we do have in Canada. But that right now is starting to feel a little bit shaky. And maybe a little bit privileged. But the rights that form the foundation for our shared values are, in fact, the very values that are helping us get through this crisis.What's remarkable about the social effectiveness of social distancing in Canada is not how many people are getting ticketed for sitting on a bench for too long or talking across their driveway. It's how many of us are actually doing the things that we're told to do. That frankly is the response of people who live in a mature democracy. That's the response of people who share values and are willing to prioritize the common good.If we toss that out the window, even if it helps right now … we're going to reduce our ability to get through another crisis like this in the future. We're going to give up who we are and what we believe, in ways that aren't just going to risk eroding rights over the long-term. It's going to risk erasing them.With some civil liberties, we're probably pretty safe. If following this pandemic, provinces continue to limit travel, for example, there would be a huge outcry. We'd say, "No way. I have mobility rights. I deserve to travel around my home country." And that would not stand in a democracy.The problem with privacy is that we're in a situation where our idea of what privacy means — even our idea of whether or not it's a fundamental human right, which it is recognized as internationally — we are in a position where the idea that privacy is something that corporations or governments can ask us to give away in exchange for a service or convenience is really fundamental. Some of these platforms that we're using to help us navigate our way through this isolation, things like video chats, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram that are allowing us to have some form of human connection during isolation are the very platforms that have habituated us to the idea that, in exchange for the privilege of using them, they get to collect information about us.That's been fundamentally built into the infrastructure of the business model and the internet, in ways that have slowly, already eroded and changed our idea of what privacy we deserve. So the risk in the pandemic is that that process is going to accelerate. And we're going to give up — not just in relation to companies but in relation to the state — the idea that privacy is actually a right and not a privilege.You've got to watch really closely for the idea that privacy is a barrier to public health — because it's not. The reality is there is nothing in privacy law that prevents sharing of epidemiological information that's necessary for public health purposes. There is nothing in privacy law that is a barrier to lawful collection of information. And what it is is a barrier to collecting personal information that's unnecessary and intrusive, that's not proportionate to the benefit that we get from it, either as individuals or as a society.The other thing that we want to watch for is the kind of proposals about tracking our risk, about coming up with some kind of system to label us as safe or unsafe people. There are so many fundamental problems with that kind of social sorting, that it's just not a place that we should be going as Canadians.Click 'listen' above to hear the full interview.

title: TRANSCRIPT SANCTIONED EPISODE 8 | CBC Radio
description: Full-text transcript for Sanctioned episode eight
content: Sanctioned - The Rule of LawHost: Stephen Quinn  Announcer: This is a CBC Podcast. [music: somber] Stephen Quinn: Previously on Sanctioned.  [music: somber] Stephen: Meng Wanzhou moves house and launches a new legal strategy in her battle against extradition, her lawyers question the actions of Canadian and American authorities at the time of her arrest. Meng claims her rights were violated the moment she stepped off a plane from Hong Kong and a videotape and transcripts, flesh out her first crucial hours in Canada. [somber music] [clip from Red Dragon plays]  [suspenseful music from film] Man: Whatever the Americans are claiming is a lie. Stephen: The movie trailer opens with a shot of a Chinese woman descending an escalator with two law enforcement officials in tow. The words, "Canada Arrests a Chinese Executive" fill the screen. Then the trailer cuts to the woman resting her head against the bars of a jail cell. [clip from Red Dragon plays]  Man: We are in an uncomfortable position because we have an extradition treaty with the Americans. [suspenseful music from film] Stephen: Words fill the screen again, "The Chinese government retaliates." [clip from Red Dragon plays]  Man: They just arbitrarily sentenced a Canadian to death, there's no telling where this retaliation will end. [suspenseful music from film] Stephen: The trailer is for the upcoming movie, "Claws of the Red Dragon."Supposedly, inspired by the dramatic situation surrounding Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou, the film stars a Canadian cast, most notably Eric Peterson, the award-winning actor perhaps best known for his role on one of the country's best-loved sitcoms, "Corner Gas". But there won't be a lot of laughs in this 54-minute thriller and it's really the name of the producer which is making headlines, not the names in the cast. It's Steve Bannon, right-wing American agitator and media mogul credited with engineering the political campaign that put U.S. President Donald Trump into office. Bannon says the fictional movie will expose ties between Huawei, known as Hua Xing in the film, and the Chinese communist government, and its military. [clip of Bannon speaking] Stephen: The backbone of the future of technology is 5G. It will be a dominant technology. Right now, the path that Huawei's taken as a front for the PLA is to basically take over the networks and the components throughout the world. If we allow this to happen, even for a couple more years, Huawei is going to control, basically, the communications systems of the west. Stephen: Huawei has repeatedly refuted such allegations. [clip from Red Dragon plays]  Man: This is a crazy accusation by countries who are jealous of our success. Stephen: "Claws of the Red Dragon" is set to be released in September,  as Meng Wanzhou, Ms. Fung in the film, prepares for two weeks of court dates ahead of her extradition hearing in January. So, is it art imitating life or is it politics imitating art and looking to influence the outcome of an ongoing drama? [clip from Red Dragon plays]  [phone rings] Woman: [speaking: Mandarin] Hello?  Stephen: Whatever the truth is, a real-life ending to Meng Wanzhou's story has yet to be written and competing storylines are about to collide. [music: Somber] Stephen: I'm Stephen Quinn and you're listening to Sanctioned: the Arrest of a Telecom Giant, a CBC Vancouver original podcast about Huawei Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou and her fight against possible extradition and jailing in the United States for allegedly violating economic sanctions against Iran. It is a journey deep into the world of global business and politics, up front deals and allegations of back room skullduggery in the battle to dominate the economies of the future, not to mention the extraordinary wealth and power of a few of the world's most influential players. Stephen: In this episode, entertaining though "Claws of the Red Dragon" promises to be, we'll look beyond fiction to the facts which led to the Chinese conflict with Canada. We'll also look beyond Vancouver to the streets of Hong Kong, Meng's other home, and the scene of her alleged crime, where China is facing pressure from its own citizens, even as it is placing pressure on Canadians. And tensions in Canada will reach a boiling point as a former Prime Minister weighs in.This is Sanctioned, Episode 8: The Rule of Law. [music: somber] Stephen: Jean Chretien was the Prime Minister of Canada on July 1st, 1997. On that day, the stroke of midnight marked the historic handover of what had been the British colony of Hong Kong back to the Chinese. [news clips play] [music: regal] Reporter: A century and a half of British rule in Hong Kong is simply history tonight. Man: I am the 28the. Governor. The last governor, my wife, my children and myself will take Hong Kong home in our hearts. Reporter 2: They left us to the call of trumpets echoing across the Pearl River. A long goodbye that ended with a wave. Stephen: And July 1st also happened to be Canada Day, so there were fireworks on both sides of the globe. Chretien is known to friends and foes alike as the self-styled little guy from Shawinigan, a scrappy fighter and perennial underdog who always seems to come out on top. In his youth, Chretien suffered from an attack of Bell's palsy, permanently leaving the left side of his face paralyzed. Stephen: As veteran foreign correspondent Jonathan Manthorpe says, it's a condition that, along with his strong Quebec accent, Chretien has used to endear himself to the public and to obscure sharp political skills with an everyman veneer.  [clip Jonathan Manthorpe speaking] Jonathan Manthorpe: He was a very eminent lawyer. He was Minister of Justice. He was actually, initially made his parliamentary name in the Pierre Trudeau cabinet as Minister of what was then called Indian Affairs. So, as you say, the sort of scrappy street fighter from the boonies of Quebec was the image he'd like to cultivate, but he was actually a very sophisticated and accomplished man. Stephen: By 1993, Chretien had risen to the post of Prime Minister himself. He would be the last Liberal to form a majority government, until Justin Trudeau took office in 2015.Chretien resigned more than a decade earlier, in the midst of allegations that later became known as "the Sponsorship Scandal", a uniquely Canadian morass of corruption,  payoffs, and misuse of public funds, centred around the actions of the Liberals in Chretien's home province. But back to 1997, when Chretien, along with the rest of the world, watched the birth of a new day in Kong Kong and what became known in China as the era of "One country, two systems".    [news clips play] [music: regal] [man speaks in Mandarin] Stephen: In his first term as Prime Minister, Jean Chretien led the largest foreign trade delegation to China in the years following the Tiananmen Square massacre. [news clips play] Reporter: Scattered protests continue to sputter and there are new reports of skirmishes and violence in the wake of this weekend's massive military assault aimed at smashing China's pro-democracy demonstrations. [sounds: protesting ] Reporter 2: The troops have been firing indiscriminately, but still, there are thousands of  people on the streets who will not move back. Reporter 3:  As the army units approached the centre of the city, they were firing into side streets, killing and injuring scores of comprehending and unarmed men women and children. Stephen: Although China has never acknowledged the slaughter of hundreds, possibly thousands, of student protesters by its army in 1989, Jonathan Manthorpe says Chretien's overtures helped reboot Canada's relationship with the Chinese government. [clip of Jonathan Manthorpe speaking]  Jonathan: China, Chinese Communist Party was still in international purgatory of sanctions because of that incident. In fact, it was a national uprising. There were similar massacres in about a hundred or so cities around China. It wasn't just in Tiananmen Square, it was much more significant than that and I think the Chinese Communist Party at that point looked to Chretien to help them out of the international doldrums in which they'd been thrust because of the massacre. Stephen: The relationship between Canada and the Chinese communist government dates back more than 50 years, to a point when Pierre Trudeau began negotiations with the People's Republic of China in order to open diplomatic relations with the communist giant and at its core, the relationship relies on a belief that is embraced by politicians of all stripes, Canadian and otherwise, politicians who seek to take advantage of China's great economic possibilities, even as they cast a wary eye to the human rights abuses of a dictatorship. It's the idea that you could embrace the light of the communist country without sacrificing anything to its darkness. Stephen: In his post-political life, Chretien continued to make frequent visits to China as part of his work with an elite law firm. He had earned the respect of Chinese governments, past and present, so it made sense that in early June 2019, another former Canadian Prime Minister, a rival even, Brian Mulroney suggested Jean Chretien might be just the man to sweeten Canada's suddenly poisoned relationship with China. Stephen: The idea is to win the release of Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, the two Canadians who had been imprisoned in China and accused of spying, and to rebuild Canada's trade relationship with China, which had banned Canadian canola and meat, all implemented in the wake of Meng Wanzhou's arrest.  As it turned out, Jean Chretien was more than willing to step into the fray once again, but perhaps not in the way that current Prime Minister Justin Trudeau might have hoped. [music: somber] Stephen: On June 12th, just as the Globe and Mail newspaper was putting the finishing touches on a bombshell of a story about Jean Chretien and Meng Wanzhou, riot police hit the streets of Hong Kong. [news clips play] Reporter: It's absolute chaos here on the streets of Hong Kong.  As you can see behind me, there were literally tens of thousands of pro-democracy supporters out here tonight, rallying against the Government's proposal to change extradition laws. Woman: [speaking: in an alternate language] Translator: I think the most important thing is to oppose this evil law.  Reporter 2: The police are also adopting more aggressive tactics, moving in faster and for the first time firing rubber bullets and beanbag rounds. Methods, Amnesty International has criticised as excessive force. Stephen: Police were sent out to quell growing protests against proposed legislation that would have further blurred the lines of the so-called 'One country, two systems' relationship between the Chinese mainland and the Hong Kong special administrative region.Ironically enough, given Meng's current predicament, the subject of the legislation was extradition. If enacted, the law would allow authorities in Hong Kong to detain and extradite suspects to mainland China and Taiwan to face trial. Critics complained that the rule would expose a population that was promised relative autonomy back in 1997 to the arbitrary and unjust realities of the Chinese legal system. [clip of Ivy Li speaking]   Ivy Li: Everyone in Hong Kong knows that China or anybody in China that can corrupt the officials and use any charges to try and get at people that they don't like or don't want. So, that is where the Hong Kong people are saying, if this amendment bill will pass, it means that everyone in Hong Kong will be at risk. Doesn't matter, you're a businessman or you are just an ordinary citizen or you are dissident. Stephen: Ivy Li, with the group Canadian Friends of Hong Kong, says erosion of the rights and freedoms of Hong Kongers started long before this extradition bill was proposed, and so the bill is really just the tip of the iceberg, there are much, much deeper political and socio-economic grievances. So in the days that followed the initial protests, the crowds grew and Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam, eventually announced the suspension of the bill and then later, even a withdrawal, but despite grave warnings from the Chinese government and increasingly violent police crackdowns, the protests in Hong Kong continued and civilians fought fire with fire.  Stephen: Lawyers, students, professors, waiters, housewives, grandparents, a sea of opponents eventually drew up a list of five core demands: complete withdrawal of the extradition bill,  the release of protesters, an independent commission into police conduct, the resignation of Carrie Lam, and universal suffrage. [clip of Ivy Li speaking]   Ivy: Because people start to realize that all these things they're seeing is only a symptom. The real solution to it, is to have to fight for universal suffrage so they can actually elect their own government. Doesn't matter how many times that the chief executives resign, step down. It will only be replaced by another puppet. So, even if the extradition bill is being withdrawn, Hong Kong will not be safe anymore because the police are behaving like the citizens are their enemies. So, people are saying that no, it's too late, too little. Stephen: Ivy, what was it like for you, or what is it like for you because those protests continue. What is it like for you to be watching what's going on there now from this far away? What do you think of what you've been seeing? Ivy: Um, it is very sad because it is a very beautiful, vibrant city and even though I left it for so many years, I still have family and friends back there. I know that Hong Kong would not be the same. Stephen: If unrest in Hong Kong, troubling though it may be, seems like a long way from the plight of Meng Wanzhou, remember, her story and the dilemma Canada is facing are both very much wrapped up in the tensions of that city.CBC reporter Jason Proctor's here to explain. Hello Jason. Jason Proctor: Hi, Stephen. Stephen: What does all this political unrest in Hong Kong have to do with Meng Wanzhou? Jason: Well, you want to think about Hong Kong in this whole story as almost this kind of third background character to all of this drama. Meng Wanzhou had actually flown from Hong Kong to Vancouver on the day she was arrested. According to the notes of the Canada Border Services agent who detained Meng in the hours after she stepped off the plane in December, she said she had traveled on a Hong Kong passport because she'd relinquished her People's Republic of China passport. Jason: So, in addition to the two Vancouver properties she owns in Canada, she has three apartments in London. Interestingly Monk said she also owned four more homes, two in Hong Kong, and two just across the border with mainland China in Shenzhen. You know, those properties reflect the realities of a life for a woman like Meng Wanzhou who does billionaire business in both the East and the West, in Hong Kong and in mainland China. Stephen: And Huawei's headquarters are actually based in Shenzhen. Yeah, Shenzhen is the first special economic zone that was established by China in 1980 for citizens to experiment with market capitalism it was in the back room of a restaurant in Hong Kong though that Meng travelled when she wanted, you know, allegedly to reassure an HSBC executive that the company was not breaking U.S. sanctions in the sort of action that gave rise to this whole case. Stephen: As Meng's father Ren Zhengfei had proven, China's "experiment" with capitalism, at this point, was beyond successful, but now, with the world watching, the Chinese military was beginning to amass in  Meng's other home in Shenzhen, which was a message, you know, an implied threat, you might say to the protesters on the other side of the border in Hong Kong and, you know, it was that kind of threat, veiled or naked, that figured into the thinking of the thousands of people who fled Hong Kong before the handover to China in 1997, landing in British Columbia, Canada, and now people in Canada and particularly in British Columbia were keeping a keen eye on this growing conflict. [music: somber] Stephen: Protesters and counter protesters in Vancouver would mirror the battles on Hong Kong's streets in much the same way that Meng's supporters would face off against her detractors on the steps of the courthouse where she fought for bail and in every case,  allegations were hurled back and forth about the potential influence of the Chinese state. Stephen: The front page headline in the Globe and Mail on June 13th caught the eye of the Canadian government almost immediately."Chretien proposes cancelling Meng's extradition case to unfreeze relations with China."The story went on to say that former Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, in private conversations with business executives, had been floating the idea that Canada's Justice Minister should exert his authority to end the extradition process against Meng. Stephen: The story said the proposal had not yet been formally presented to the Trudeau government, but that it would meet Chinese president Xi Jinping's demand that Meng be freed to return home to Beijing, as a means to ramp down reprisals that extended beyond the Canadians marking time in a Chinese prison, to the thousands of farmers whose livelihoods were being threatened by the Chinese bans on Canadian agricultural products. Now, it's true that Justice Minister David Lametti could intervene in Meng's extradition proceeding at any time, it is, after all, within the legislation, but as Paul Evans with the School of Public Policy and Global Affairs at UBC told me, this provision has never been acted upon by a Canadian justice minister.  [clip of Paul Evans speaking]  Paul Evans: Some lawyers would make the case that it shouldn't be acted upon, but nevertheless, it is not undue interference in a legal proceeding. It is something that has been anticipated in the legislation from the outset. Secondly, I think that if a current justice minister or a future justice minister, we don't know the outcome of the election, but that a future minister and government would have to start preparing the ground for the Canadian public and preparing the ground for the United States. Stephen: And that would be a huge issue with the United States, if the Minister stepped in to end the extradition proceedings. Paul: It would be. It would be unprecedented and particularly in the context of the major U.S. confrontation with China, which, there may be some magic, but at the moment, it looks like this is building towards a multidimensional confrontation, that for Canada to make a decision to release Madam Meng, that would need a lot of explaining and a lot of courage by any government that wished to do it. Stephen: Canada's Foreign Affairs Minister, Chrystia Freeland almost immediately rejected Chretien's suggestion. [clip of Chrystia Freeland speaking] Chrystia Freeland: When it comes to the extradition request around Ms. Meng, Canada has very carefully and intentionally abided by our extradition treaty commitments and, I think, when we reflect on it, it would be clear to all of us that it would be a very dangerous precedent indeed for Canada to alter its behaviour when it comes to honouring an extradition treaty in response to external pressure. Stephen:  But Chretien's proposal had raised a point that in some ways,  touched the heart of Canada's conflict with China, and the many underlying tensions. [music: somber] Stephen: What is the value of one individual, as measured against the interests of the wider population or the desires of the state? It's the kind of question Chretien himself had faced in 1997, when RCMP pepper sprayed protesters at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting at the University of British Columbia, a stone's throw from Meng's mansion. Chretien was accused of sacrificing the Canadian right to free speech  to save an Indonesian dictator from embarrassment. At the time, Chretien even joked about the effects of pepper spray. [clip of Chretien speaking] Jean Chretien: For me, I put pepper on my plate. [crowd laughs] Jean: Next. Stephen: And now, nearly a quarter century later, Chretien was suggesting that the rule of extradition law take a back seat to Canada's economic interests with China, a country that is allegedly holding Canadians hostage to get its way, a country that, even as the Meng Wanzhou drama was playing out, was threatening to crack down on peaceful protesters who were marching in Hong Kong in the millions, demanding their rights. Stephen: This was an awkward time for Canada to be having this conversation. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government was facing a rule of law scandal of its own, grounded in an allegation that he had attempted to force his attorney general into giving Canadian engineering giant SNC Lavalin, a break on a criminal case that could have killed the company. Trudeau claimed he was putting Canadian jobs first. Chretien was suggesting he do just that, by freeing Meng Wanzhou and Meng's lawyers were listening. [music: somber] Stephen: The statement came out as a blast email, jointly signed by all four of Meng Wanzhou's lawyers. Canada, they said, was at a crossroads, and Canadian values were at stake. Jason Proctor's back with me now. So Jason, what exactly were Meng's lawyers trying to say here?  Jason: They cited former Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien's comments as the impetus for what they claimed was an appeal to Canada's Minister of Justice to drop the extradition proceedings against their client Meng Wanzhou, and I'll read from their statement, because it was fairly extraordinary. Quote, "from time to time, Canadian governments have had to make difficult decisions, sometimes at odds with the foreign policy initiatives of its allies, including the United States, in order to assert essential Canadian values of human decency, fairness, tolerance and respect for human rights and the rule of law," end quote, and that was from this statement. Stephen: Except that tolerance and respect for human rights were not the only factors at play here. Jason: No, certainly not. And they weren't front and centre in the argument being put forward through, you know, the Globe Mail story on Chretien. Meng's lawyers claimed the cessation of the proceedings would be in the best interests of Canada's national interests and they went on to underscore a point that would become central to their argument for Meng's freedom because, well, only the United States has sanctions prohibiting foreign banks from entering into U.S. dollar transactions with foreign companies selling commercial goods in Iran.  Jason: So, what they say is man's alleged crime wouldn't be a crime in Canada, and again this is quoting from the statement, "Canada does not police the conduct of foreign persons in foreign lands that have nothing to do with Canada". That's from the statement and Meng's lawyers backed up their argument with another page from Chretien's book. [music: somber] Stephen: On February 15th, 2003, crowds began streaming into downtown Vancouver. Their destination? The art gallery. Once a provincial courthouse, the hundred-year-old building that houses the gallery was renovated in the 1980s by Arthur Erickson, part of the same complex of buildings where Meng Wanzhou would later face trial. Stephen: The gallery has served as a locus for protest for decades and in 2003, with a U.S. led war against Iraq imminent, more than 40,000 people gathered in the streets, joining millions around the world to oppose the invasion. [clips from Iraq war protests] Man: We are here to send a message of hope and solidarity for the people of Iraq. Woman: We are here today because we want to say to the Canadian government, have the courage to stand up and speak out and stop this war. Do not be complicit in the war on Iraq. Stephen: Just a few months earlier, Prime Minister Jean Chretien announced that Canada would not be part of the American coalition. It was a controversial move at the time, one that spurred debate, but it proved that Canada can go it alone when national interest was at stake. So now, years later,  Meng Wanzhou's lawyers are pointing to that decision as evidence that Canada can stand up to the pressures of its allies. [music: somber] Stephen: Ironically, David Lametti, the justice minister who was the target of Meng's appeal, had just taking over for Jody Wilson-Raybould, the Liberal politician who claimed she had stood up to her own government in order to defend the rule of law when it came to the prosecution of the engineering giant SNC Lavalin. As foreign affairs minister Chrystia Freeland acknowledged to the CBC, if Meng was committed for extradition, there would come a point when Lametti would have to make a decision, no matter what, as to whether Meng should be sent to the United States. Saying you're a rule of law country doesn't mean political decisions don't get taken, Freeland said. And in fact, Jason, the political element of the extradition process is actually baked right into the law. Jason: Well, yeah, it is. You know, in 2001, Canada's top court, Supreme Court of Canada decided not to extradite four men wanted in the United States for a 22 million dollar telemarketing scam. So, the reason in that case, which has precedent with regards to, you know, the situation Meng Wanzhou is in, it was from comments that American prosecutors made to a CBC show, The Fifth Estate, implying that one of the accused would be "the boyfriend of a very bad man", if he waited out his extradition hearing and wound up in a U.S. jail. Jason: So, the men involved at the center of that case, argued that they were being threatened with rape in prison, and that would be a violation of the very same Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms that  Meng Wanzhou was arguing, should act as a shield for her against the actions of authorities determined to put her behind bars. So this was a case when the courts essentially said, the Minister of Justice should have refused a request from the United States or should have at least stepped in and overruled the court. Meng's lawyers claimed this was another one of those times, they urged the Canadian government to stand up for Canadian values.  [somber music] Stephen: But what exactly would that mean? Should the Canadian government support the legal request of an ally, or give into the bullying tactics of a valued trading partner?It was a conundrum Lametti would have to ponder, even as tanks gathered in Shenzhen, thousands of protesters linked arms in Hong Kong and the world watched. It was to be a summer of discontent in Hong Kong, Vancouver, and in Washington, where rumours of a recession began dogging U.S. President Donald Trump. [news clips play] Donald Trump: I don't see a recession. I mean, the world is in a recession right now. Woman: Over the next 12 months the recession probability is above 80 percent. Reporter: Democrats pin the blame on the White House's trade war with China. Presidential candidate, Pete Buttigieg. Pete Buttigieg:  But it's also a fool's errand to think you're gonna be able to get China to change the fundamentals of their economic model by poking them in the eye with some tariffs. Stephen: The trade battle between the U.S. and China had become tit for tat and with Christmas looming, American consumers were starting to feel the pain of billions of dollars worth of tariffs and American farmers began to grumble about the impact of Chinese retaliation, which was beginning to hurt their pocketbooks.Trump's Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, tried to walk back the president's suggestion that Meng Wanzhou might be used as a bargaining chip.  [clip of Mike Pompeo speaking] Mike Pompeo: We've been pretty clear, with respect to the way we process and ask other countries with respect to extradition. I expect this case will be no different from that attorney general bar and the Justice Department team have a process by which they evaluate anytime they ask for this extradition which is a big lift oftentimes, certainly in this case, it is as well. They were thoughtful in the request and they'll continue to accord with American law and international law in the way that they proceed. I'm very confident of that.  Stephen: Movie audiences braced themselves for the release of "Claws of the Red Dragon"  [clip from Red Dragon plays]  Woman: This is a democracy, reporters write the truth, editors allow that truth to be published, the legal system operates without interference, full stop. Stephen: And court watchers prepared for the next episode of the legal drama, when Meng's lawyers would face prosecutors in court for the first real legal skirmish in the fight, a fight ahead of the extradition hearing itself, a battle for disclosure of notes, documents, and correspondence between Canadian and U.S. authorities in the leadup to Meng's arrest. It would likely be the next time the world got a glimpse of the embattled Huawei CFO, a court appearance taking place weeks before a Canadian election, where the rule of law, the relationship with China, and the future of 5G would all be on the table. Meng Wanzhou would still face extradition after the election, but would her situation come to haunt a new Canadian government? [music: somber] Stephen: This is our last episode for now,  but we expect to be back with more as events warrant in the coming months. One big date to keep an eye out for is January of 2020, that's when Meng Wanzhou's actual extradition hearing will begin. In the meantime, stay tuned to CBC for all the latest developments in the story. [music: somber] Stephen: I'm Stephen Quinn. Sanctioned is written by Jason Proctor, our associate producers are Vivian Luck and Rachel Sanders. It's mixed by Jeff Walter. Teresa Duvall is our executive producer and you can download episode eight at cbc.ca/podcasts or on iTunes, where you can also offer up your review. [music: somber]

title: The COVID-19 pandemic: What it is, who's at risk, and how you can protect yourself | CBC News
description: Here's a breakdown of what COVID-19 is, who is most at risk of catching it, and most importantly, what you can do to protect yourself.
content: Now that the World Health Organization has declared the novel coronavirus outbreak a pandemic, shutting down cities and even an entire country, many people want to know more about what they can do to fight COVID-19.   Canada confirmed its first case on Jan. 25 and as the new virus makes its way around the world, here's a breakdown of what it is, who is most at risk, and most importantly, what you can do to protect yourself. It's the illness that's caused by a viral respiratory infection. The virus that leads to COVID-19 is known as SARS-CoV-2​​​​.Dr. Allison McGeer, a clinical scientist with Sinai Health System in Toronto, said SARS-CoV-2 probably started showing up in China in November 2019.The World Health Organization says Chinese officials first reported cases of pneumonia with an unknown cause to the WHO Country Office on Dec. 31, 2019. What we know (and don't know) about the coronavirus outbreakOverall, 80 per cent of those who get infected will have mild symptoms, said Dr. Isaac Bogoch, an infectious disease expert at University Health Network in Toronto. Severe COVID-19 cases are more common for those who are "older, immunocompromised and/or have underlying health issues," said McGeer. In February, China's centre for disease control and prevention (China CDC), published a study outlining the age and gender of 72,314 people infected with COVID-19.  The findings show that about 80 per cent of those who died from COVID-19 in China were 60 or older. In Italy, the National Health Institute says the average age of patients who have died is 81, with the majority suffering from underlying health problems."The disease in children appears to be mild," said McGeer. China CDC found that only 0.9 per cent of infections were children under the age of 10.Canada's first COVID-19 death is not cause for panic — but shows need to protect most vulnerableAccording to the World Health Organization:Proper hand hygiene, said McGeer, can greatly reduce your risk of contracting the illness.  Although using soap to thoroughly cleanse your hands is best, "if hand sanitizer is all you have, use that," said Bogoch. "Go for the hand sanitizer that has about 70 per cent alcohol," he said. The World Health Organization says the virus is spread from person-to-person through small droplets from an infected person's mouth or nose. "If you get the virus on your hands, this virus does not infect you through your skin," said McGeer. "It has to then be transmitted to your eyes, mouth or nose."  That's why it's so important to keep your hands away from your face, said Bogoch. "It's actually hard to do that in practice, but if people are mindful and don't touch their faces… they'll come into less contact with this virus," said Bogoch.COVID-19 isn't a gastrointestinal virus, said McGeer. "We've seen quarantines in China and Italy … but there's not been a circumstance in which there has been shortages of food or or basic supplies or life saving medication.," she said. If you do get sick, you will need to stay home for two weeks. Having enough food for 14 days is key, said McGeer. You should also refill your prescriptions so you have enough medication to last through a quarantine.  Though many people infected with COVID-19 may have few or no symptoms, the government of Canada's website says those symptoms include: Stay home, say both McGeer and Bogoch. The government of Canada website also outlines that if you need to see a doctor or go to the hospital because your illness is severe, call ahead or tell officials that you have a respiratory illness right when you arrive.  Canadians being urged to help 'flatten the curve' of COVID-19WHO is coordinating efforts to develop vaccines and some drug treatments are currently under investigation. But Bogoch said a vaccine is at least a year away. He said the infectious disease community believes that there are three scenarios for the future of COVID-19: "We need to develop an effective vaccine to protect communities from this infection, because it's unlikely to go away anytime soon," said Bogoch.

title: Yellowknife couple faces coronavirus on both sides of the world | CBC News
description: While Steven Shen waits for the panic to subside in China’s Guangdong province, his wife Nancy Lin confronts fear of the COVID-19 in Yellowknife.
content: It was supposed to be a retirement vacation. Steven Shen travelled to Asia with a Yellowknife couple, first to the couple's home community in the Philippines, then to his in China. Shen grew up in Chaozhou, a city of 2.6 million people in China's Guangdong province.He reached China on Jan. 18, planning to return to Yellowknife on March 3. In early February, he learned from his travel agent that his return flight to Canada, on China Eastern Airlines, was cancelled. Chaozhou is about 800 kilometres south of Wuhan, where the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, first emerged, and far from the areas where authorities have imposed a clampdown on travel. But Wuhan is a busy travel hub, which has affected routes throughout the country. Shen could have rebooked on a later flight, but he hasn't yet done so. "After consulting with my family and consulting a public health expert, they say, well, you're better to stay in China longer, and I think it is a good idea." Shen is a former environmental health officer with the N.W.T. government. He moved to Yellowknife 15 years ago to take the job. So while he wants to avoid travelling on any routes where he could be exposed to the illness, or carrying the illness himself, there's also another reason he's choosing to stay put."I want to set an example for other people."Shen's wife, Nancy Lin, says she's OK with that decision. She and the couple's daughter have been in Yellowknife the whole time, checking in with Steve by phone. "He is having a good time," Lin said. But Lin has faced her own COVID-19 battles at home. She usually travels to China over the holidays, visiting family for two weeks at a time. This year, she changed that plan in order to prepare for an exam. One afternoon in January, she was in the downtown grocery store when she saw one of her co-workers, who knows her usual pattern. "He passed by," she said, "and then realized it was me. And then he stepped two steps far away from me, which is kind of about two metres away from me, and then he stopped and turned and said, 'Hey, Nancy! Have you just come back from China?'"Obviously I can feel that two-metres distance." In China, Shen says he's already seen concern about the COVID-19 virus calm down. He spoke to the CBC from a street side tea shop and said people were smiling and out walking around."That was not the situation one month ago. People were very worried." Shen said he's also hoping to get some more information as an international traveller returning to the N.W.T., "such as guidance on isolation and prevention."So far, the territorial government has not issued any general warnings or advice on whether or not to travel — inside or outside of the country. The World Health Organization has not yet advised against any international travel.The federal government issued a travel advisory on Jan. 7 advising Canadians "to consider avoiding non-essential travel to China" and other countries affected by the COVID-19 virus. That advisory recommends travellers who do go to China avoid spending time in large crowds, avoid sick people and animals, and follow local public health advice. Travellers returning from China are asked to monitor their health for fever, cough and difficulty breathing for 14 days, and "avoid places where you cannot easily separate from others if you become ill."People who do develop symptoms are asked to isolate themselves from others as quickly as possible and contact a health-care professional.Those who have travelled to China's Hubei Province (of which Wuhan is the capital) are asked to contact the public health authority in the area where they live within 24 hours of arriving in Canada.
